qas.question: What country has first tried to use single-phase AC?
What frequency did the line of Hungarian rail system used in 1923?
What type of the converter was used in hungarian locomotives of that time?
How could the locomotives run on four speed levels?

answers.text: motor could be changed using slip rings

qas.question: What system was adopted in Hungary after WWII?
The number of poles on the 5,000 hp motor could be changed using what?
The first attempt to use standard-frequency double-phase AC were made in what country?
The locomotives carrying a three-pole rotating phase converter could feed what?
The first attempt to use standard-frequency double-phase AC were made in what year?

plausible_answers.text: the Russian and later French 25 kV system

qas.question: During the Second World War, the 16 kV was changed to what?

context: The first attempts to use standard-frequency single-phase AC were made in <a0_0><b6_0>Hungary<b6_0/><a0_0/> as far back as <b8_0>1923<b8_0/>, by the Hungarian Kálmán Kandó on the line between Budapest-Nyugati and Alag, using <a1_0>16 kV at 50 Hz<a1_0/>. The locomotives carried a <a2_0>four-pole rotating phase converter<a2_0/> feeding <b7_0>a single traction motor<b7_0/> of the polyphase induction type at 600 to 1,100 V. The number of poles on the 2,500 hp <a3_0>motor could be changed using <b5_0>slip rings<b5_0/><a3_0/> to run at one of four synchronous speeds. The tests were a success so, from 1932 until the 1960s, trains on the Budapest-Hegyeshalom line (towards Vienna) regularly used the same system. A few decades after the Second World War, the 16 kV was changed to <b9_0>the <a4_0>Russian<a4_0/> and later French 25 kV system<b9_0/>.
